headline.main: ASPIRING ROMANCE NOVELISTS SEEK WAYS TO BREATHE PASSION INTO THEIR PROSE

results.snippet: On the weekend before Valentine's Day, 298 aspiring romance novelists, mostly women, attended a convention here to learn how to write sensuous love scenes and other passionate passages.   Most of those who attended the three-day convention...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: On the weekend before Valentine's Day, 298 aspiring romance novelists, mostly women, attended a convention here to learn how to write sensuous love scenes and other passionate passages. Most of those who attended the three-day convention described themselves as homemakers, but secretaries, teachers and dental assistants also discussed the problems they faced as writers. The successful romance novelists, who write under such names as Rebecca Brandewyne, Carolyn Stromeyer Thornton and Philippa Castle, form part of a modern-day cottage industry that is a booming sector of the publishing industry. They package and publish their paperback fantasies under such titles as ''Forever My Love,'' ''Love Is Surrender,'' and ''The Reluctant Duke'' and sell them for $1.75 to $3.95.

results.snippet: WHENEVER I see a baglady, I see myself slipping past the edge of time and space into an abandoned doorway. ''We are all bagladies in our souls,'' says a friend who has certainly had her successes. She tells me of riding a bus recently when a...
results.lead_paragraph: WHENEVER I see a baglady, I see myself slipping past the edge of time and space into an abandoned doorway. ''We are all bagladies in our souls,'' says a friend who has certainly had her successes. She tells me of riding a bus recently when a baglady climbed on, heaving herself and her possesions through the door and up the steps. Some sense of pride or purpose, or both, pushed her past the seats reserved for the handicapped and elderly, down the aisle to the back where one long, overheated seat served as an inspection table for the contents of her bags. The men continued to read their papers. ''But the women became very tense, as if she were sending a current through them,'' my friend recounted. ''We sat up straighter, drew our knees together and clutched at whatever was in our laps. When she got up to leave, there wasn't a woman on that bus who didn't turn to watch her safely down the steps, and gaze after her until she was no longer in sight. But she left behind a scent of vulnerability.''

byline.original: By Laurie Johnston and Robin Herman

results.lead_paragraph: Down-to-Earth Advice From an Astronaut A lbert Thompson Jr., aged 8, took an astronaut to school yesterday. Maj. Charles F. Bolden Jr. visited the St. Ignatius school, on East 84th Street. Then he went to Harlem to the St. Charles school, on West 143d Street and Intermediate School 136, on West 136th.

headline.main: Navy Astronaut Will Be First To Fly Space Shuttle 3 Times

results.snippet: Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy, who piloted the first flight of the space shuttle Columbia, has been named as commander of the 13th shuttle flight, making him the first astronaut to take a shuttle into space three times.   The mission of...
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy, who piloted the first flight of the space shuttle Columbia, has been named as commander of the 13th shuttle flight, making him the first astronaut to take a shuttle into space three times. The mission of flight 13, now scheduled for April 1984, will be the first to test the shuttle's ability to retrieve and repair a satellite in space. The shuttle Challenger will attempt to repair a sun-study satellite that has been malfunctioning for five years.

results.snippet: AWEEK before former Vice President Walter F. Mondale officially announced the obvious yesterday, that he would seek the presidency, he was guest of honor at Alice Mason's elegant dinner, charming scores of the 60 rich, powerful and mostly...
results.lead_paragraph: AWEEK before former Vice President Walter F. Mondale officially announced the obvious yesterday, that he would seek the presidency, he was guest of honor at Alice Mason's elegant dinner, charming scores of the 60 rich, powerful and mostly Democratic guests in his warm outgoing way. Mrs. Mason is big in real estate and he sat at her right, next to Barbara Walters and across from the editors of Time and Newsweek, but he didn't allow a table heavily freighted with news people to become a news conference nor to pin him down on the specifics. Yet he left indelible tracks. He'd barely seated himself before wondering about the Reagan Administration's arms control tactics, arguing that this was a big issue with the voters, didn't Henry A. Grunwald of Time agree? And by the time the salmon mousse arrived, he was dealing with crime. ''We must build more prisons,'' he declared. ''Crime is a big issue?'' he asked Mr. Grunwald, the details of whose noncommital answer were lost when Miss Walters asked Mr. Mondale whom he thought was his chief Democratic competitor, and he named Ohio's Senator John Glenn.

headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE FLIGHT IS EXPECTED IN MARCH AFTER 2-MONTH DELAY

results.snippet: A second replacement engine has passed testing and the space shuttle Challenger should be ready for launching on its maiden flight March 19 or 20, the shuttle director, Lieut. Gen. James Abrahamson, said today.   General Abrahamson said that...
results.lead_paragraph: A second replacement engine has passed testing and the space shuttle Challenger should be ready for launching on its maiden flight March 19 or 20, the shuttle director, Lieut. Gen. James Abrahamson, said today. General Abrahamson said that despite the two months' delay in the launching caused by leaks in two main engines, the space agency would run a round-the-clock operation at the Kenconduct five shuttle flights this year. Plans call for a mission by the Challenger in late May and a third in late July.
